speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we've got time for one more call.  Roz, who've we got?

speaker: Roz
text: We have Sid in Bremerton on three.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Sid.  I'm listening.

speaker: Sid
text: [_stiltedly_] Hello, Dr. Crane.  I have a terrible fear of talking on the phone to people I do not know.  I freeze up. It is a severe handicap in today's fast-paced, highly competitive world.

speaker: Frasier
text: Sid, are you reading what you're saying?

speaker: Sid
text: Uh... [_shuffling papers_] Yes, I am.  The only way I can comfortably communicate on the phone is to write everything out I wish to say in advance.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, what if someone asks you a question you haven't anticipated?

speaker: Sid
text: Uhhhh... [_shuffling papers_] Thank you, Dr. Crane, for your most insightful comment.  G-Goodbye. [_hangs up_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Wait, Sid!  Sid, if you're listening, your insecurity is rooted in your fear of making a mistake.  In order to beat this thing, you're going to have to practice.  If you work at it very hard.  Then, one day, you too may achieve the command and confidence to which we all aspire to... be having. [_confused look_] This is Dr. Frasier Crane, wishing you good mental health.

speaker: Roz
text: That was a show good, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Roz.

speaker: Niles
text: Knock, knock!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles!  What are you doing here?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, just stopped by to see how you'd like to go to lunch next week at the Empire Club.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know someone who's a member?

speaker: Niles
text: No, but you may.

speaker: Frasier
text: What are you up to?  You have that same smug look you had on your face when you found that recording of Kirsten Flagstad's 1932 _Gotterdammerung_ in the discount bin.

speaker: Niles
text: If you think I look smug now, wait till you see me next week. If all goes well, my lapel will be sagging under the weight of a solid gold membership pin.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, you'll certainly fit right in with all those greedy, arrogant bluebloods who wouldn't cross the street to spit on the rest of us.

speaker: Niles
text: Don't jinx it, Roz, I'm not in yet.  There's still the cocktail party next week where they screen prospective members, and from what I hear, those can be grueling.

speaker: Frasier
text: So, how did this all come about?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, really I give the credit to Maris.  She spent five years carefully cultivating the right relationships until finally this week, fortune smiled upon us: Old Judge Clement suffered a massive stroke, and, lo! a vacancy opened up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gives new meaning to the phrase, "a stroke of luck."

speaker: Niles
text: It gets better!  There are actually two vacancies, so my chances are double.  Edgar Van Cortland has been indicted in that savings and loans scandal.  Frasier, I think my time has come.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm very happy for you.

speaker: Niles
text: That's very generous of you, especially knowing you've always dreamed of a membership yourself.  A lesser man would be jealous. [_beat_] You're not, are you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Not at all.

speaker: Niles
text: Did I mention that they have a planetarium on the third floor?

speaker: Frasier
text: So?!

speaker: Niles
text: I think my work here is done. _Niles exits.  Frasier picks up his briefcase and walks into Roz's booth._

speaker: Roz
text: So, Niles is getting into the Empire Club?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it would appear so.  More power to him.  After all, he deserves to have lunch in that private dining room, and read the _Wall Street Journal_ in that fabled mahogany library...

speaker: Roz
text: It's eating you up inside, isn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Like a carnivorous bacteria.  If he gets into that club I should too!

speaker: Roz
text: [_picking up phone and dialing_] Well, what if I happen to know someone very high up who could probably get you invited to that cocktail party?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Roz, don't toy with me!

speaker: Roz
text: [_into phone_] Mr. Strickland, please.  Just tell him it's Roz.

speaker: Frasier
text: Walter Strickland, Jr?!

speaker: Roz
text: Senior.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_gasps_] Roz, how did you ever get to know someone so important?

speaker: Roz
text: The less you know the happier you'll be. _FADE OUT  Scene Two -- Frasier's Apartment Daphne, her hair done up in curlers, is ironing clothes on the dining table.  Martin enters with Eddie. _

speaker: Martin
text: Whew!  I think I need more comfortable shoes.  My dogs are killing me.

speaker: Daphne
text: Pardon?

speaker: Martin
text: My dogs.  My feet.  What do you call them in England?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, we mostly call our body parts by their rightful names. Except my uncle Harold.  He named parts of his anatomy after the royal family.  He walked on the Queen's pins, he sat on the Duchess of Kent.  He was quite a jolly fellow.  That is, until Aunt Kate caught him introducing the Prince of Wales to a cocktail waitress.

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, are you almost finished with that?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes I am, Dr. Crane.  You'll have the handsomest midriff at the Club tonight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  I hope my date concurs.

speaker: Martin
text: Who are you taking to this shindig?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dr. Susan Anderson.  She's as boring as unbuttered toast, but she's a brilliant physician, and been socially well- connected.

speaker: Martin
text: Isn't Niles a little ticked off at you horning in on his big party?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes, he was, at first.  But, then I convinced him that we could be of help to each other.  If we work together, we can secure both vacancies.

speaker: Martin
text: Boy, you and Niles -- it's been the same since you were kids. If one of you has something, the other one always has to have it too. [_the doorbell rings_] I had to buy two Balinese lutes, two decoupage kits, two pairs of lederhosen.  When you finally moved out of the house that was one embarrassing garage sale.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Ready to go?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, actually, I'm still waiting on Susan; she's at the hospital.

speaker: Martin
text: Where's Maris?

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, she stayed in the Mercedes, practicing her vivacious giggle.  Let's go over our strategy.  I've prepared a crib sheet on each person on the membership committee. There you are... _Frasier and Niles sit on the couch.  Niles takes some practice cards out of his pocket and gives them to Frasier._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hmm... School ties... business affiliations... hobbies... mistresses.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, oh, oh!  Now I've also done some research on our competition, and frankly, I don't think we have to worry.  One of them flies coach.

speaker: Frasier
text: We're as good as in!

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, yes...

speaker: Frasier
text: Unless... oh, Niles!  I just had the most terrifying thought.

speaker: Niles
text: Hmm?

speaker: Frasier
text: What if some other candidate has gone to the trouble of researching... the skeletons in our own closet? _Frasier and Niles slowly look to Martin, who is opening a beer. Beer sprays all over his face, after which he attempts to wipe it off with his shirt._

speaker: Niles
text: Well, that's as bad as it gets.

speaker: Frasier
text: I wouldn't be so sure.  I don't think the membership committee would look kindly on your being arrested for mooning President Nixon at the campaign rally.

speaker: Niles
text: I was young and firm and in love with an anarchist.  Besides, that's pretty minor compared to your suicide attempt.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_indignantly_] It was not a legitimate attempt.  I only stepped out on that ledge to get Lilith's attention.

speaker: Niles
text: [_getting up_] Oh, you know Frasier, perhaps Maris and I should head on over without you.  We can't have the other candidates getting a leg up on us.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's a good idea, Niles.  I'll see you there.

speaker: Niles
text: Alright.  Bye, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Good luck.

speaker: Niles
text: Thanks.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_answering phone_] Hello?  Oh, Susan, Susan!  Oh my goodness, I've been expecting you.  Are you in the car?  Oh no, you're still at the hospital?  Well, of course I understand.  Well, you were a sweetheart to agree to go in the first place. I'll call you tomorrow. [_hangs up_] Fat chance.

speaker: Martin
text: Stood you up, huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: This is disastrous!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, just go stag.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I've RSVP'd for two.  I'll look like some loser who couldn't even scrape up a date.

speaker: Martin
text: Wait a minute.  What are we worried about?  We've got our very own Cinderella right under this roof.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, that's the last time I try to get grout up without wearing rubber gloves.  I've got so much gunk under my nails I look like I've been worming a pig.

speaker: Martin
text: [_to Frasier_] Trust me, the English accent'll sell it.  _Frasier looks dubious.  FADE TO:_  **THE CRANE SCRUTINY**  _Scene Three -- The Empire Club Frasier and Daphne enter a very luxuriously furnished clubroom. Men in crisp tuxedos mingle, drinking expensive liqueurs.  Frasier is dazzled by the opulence of the club._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh... oh, yes... oh, it's everything I've ever imagined it would be and more!

speaker: Daphne
text: What's that smell, Dr. Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_breathlessly_] That's power.  Oh, Daphne, listen, call me Frasier.  I don't want people to know that you work for me, all right?  If they ask, we've been dating for six months.

speaker: Daphne
text: Alright, Frasier. [_she laughs_]  Anything else, Frasier? Now, are we in love, or is this just a physical thing, Frasier?  [_she grins_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, now just stop that! _Frasier and Daphne walk in arm in arm.  Suddenly they spot Niles, who rushes over to greet them._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles, Niles!  How goes the chase?

speaker: Niles
text: Brilliantly! [_he sees Daphne; breathlessly_] Daphne!

speaker: Daphne
text: Evening, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: What are you doing here?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, Frasier takes me everywhere, don't you, sweetheart? I think I'll go sample some of the hors d'oeuvres. Back in a minute, darling.

speaker: Niles
text: [_apoplectic_] "Sweetheart?"  "Darling?"

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen, my date canceled, Daphne's filling in, all right? You can't honestly think that I would end up going out with Daphne?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you are a man.  She is a goddess... whose bedroom is, after all, only forty-one steps from your own.

speaker: Frasier
text: On a completely unrelated topic, where's Maris?

speaker: Niles
text: The last I saw, she was apologizing to one of the other candidate's wives.  Apparently, Maris bumped an entire chafing dish of crabmeat into the poor woman's decolletage.

speaker: Frasier
text: Accidents will happen.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  As long as they keep the hors d'oeuvres flowing, they will.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_gasps_] My god!  Niles, feel this leather!  Oh, I have had pudding stiffer than this!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Frasier! [_points to a man filling a pipe nearby_] Kenneth Spencer! _Frasier and Niles take out a small blue index card, scan its contents, and stroll over to Kenneth Spencer._

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Niles, I'm sure it was very satisfying being Phi Beta Kappa at Yale, but surely you would have been happier to wear the orange and black of Princeton.

speaker: Niles
text: Of course, anyone who's anyone went to Princeton.

speaker: Spencer
text: Excuse me, I'm Kenneth Spencer.  I couldn't help but overhear you.  As it happens, I went to Princeton.

speaker: Frasier/Niles
text: [_seemingly surprised_] Oh, no!

speaker: Niles
text: What are the odds?

speaker: Frasier
text: Allow me. [_shaking hands_] I'm Dr. Frasier Crane, and this is my brother, Dr. Niles Crane, the eminent psychiatrist.

speaker: Niles
text: My brother is too kind.  He was already eminent when my eminence was merely imminent.

speaker: Daphne
text: Here, try this caviar, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm sorry it took so long, but I met the most charming gentleman, Edgar Van Cortland.

speaker: Frasier
text: Van Cortland?  I thought he lost his membership in the S & L scandal.

speaker: Spencer
text: Actually, he was acquitted of all charges and reinstated in the club.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, he was innocent?

speaker: Spencer
text: No, just acquitted. _He chuckles, and the Crane men join in, but the shift in Frasier and Niles's attitudes is immediate and drastic._

speaker: Niles
text: So does that mean that there's only one membership?

speaker: Spencer
text: Yes - oh, but not to worry.  If one of you should be selected, you can always bring the other along as a guest.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, if only one of us can be honored with a membership, I hope it will be you, Frasier.

speaker: Spencer
text: That's a very noble sentiment.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I know how much it means to him.  We can't risk another splashy suicide attempt. _Frasier chuckles lightly, and puts a brotherly arm around Niles's shoulders._

speaker: Frasier
text: That's very amusing, Niles, using humor to defuse a tense situation.  I'm sure that stood you in good stead when you were in prison for threatening the president. _Niles is about to object, when Frasier squeezes his collarbone enough to make him gasp.  Mr. Drake, the club president, calls from across the room._

speaker: Drake
text: Kenneth?  Kenneth!

speaker: Spencer
text: Excuse me. _Kenneth Spencer moves off.  Niles and Frasier begin bickering furiously, with Niles yelping in pain as Frasier tightens his grip on him.  Daphne finally stops them._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, stop it!  Do you intend to stand there running each other down and ruin both your chances?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no.

speaker: Niles
text: Of course you're right.

speaker: Daphne
text: Thank you.

speaker: Wentworth
text: Cocktails, gentlemen?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes, I'd like two ounces of your best 18-year-old Lowland single malt scotch.

speaker: Drake
text: [_sitting in one of the armchairs_] There's a discriminating choice.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, my brother has an extensive knowledge of fine wines and spirits - undoubtedly acquired during the years when he was shacked up with a barmaid.  _Niles gives a light chuckle, and hurries off.  Frasier smiles at Drake, and chases after Niles.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene Four -- Cafe Nervosa Frasier and Roz are sitting at a table in the corner._

speaker: Roz
text: So my mom says, "how come you never bring your boyfriends out to meet me?"  And I say, "Mom, the plane trip to Wisconsin takes four hours, and that's longer than most of my relationships last."

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, there's Niles.  No, don't look at him!  Pretend we don't even see him.

speaker: Roz
text: Real mature, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks to that backstabber, I will never get to say the phrase I've been rehearsing for a lifetime: "If you need me, I'll be at my club."

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, this is so boring!  Don't you both owe each other an apology?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes!  But I was the first to apologize last time. Oh, wait - that means it's his turn!  Oh, goody, I _can_ be mature about this!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: After last night's behavior, I believe an apology is in order.

speaker: Niles
text: I agree... Well?

speaker: Frasier
text: "Well," what?

speaker: Niles
text: It's your turn.  I apologized first last time.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, you didn't!

speaker: Niles
text: I did so!  I distinctly remember.  It was after that shouting match at the Monet exhibit.  I had my secretary leave a heartfelt apology with your service.

speaker: Frasier
text: So you did.  That means it is my turn again... Damn! [_he pauses_] I'm sorry.

speaker: Niles
text: Me too!

speaker: Frasier
text: I can't believe we just turned on each other like that.

speaker: Niles
text: It was embarrassing.  My only excuse is that all my life, I have dreamed of belonging to an exclusive club like the Empire.  Even as a child, when I formed clubs with my teddy bears, there were always two or three who didn't make the cut.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello?  Yes, this is Dr. Crane. [_to Frasier_] It's the club. [_into phone_] Yes?  I see.  Well, thank you for considering me.  If you'd care to speak to my brother he's right here. [_he hands the phone to Frasier:_] Be gracious.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_dejectedly_] Hello?  Yes, I see.  Thank you very much for calling.  Goodbye. [_he hangs up and stares at the table_]

speaker: Niles
text: Don't let it get you down.  We got along fine without them before and we'll get along fine now. [_Frasier is silent_] We are getting along without them, aren't we?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles...

speaker: Niles
text: Oh my god... you got in.

speaker: Niles
text: ...Congratulations.  I'd better go break the news to Maris. [_he gets up_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Believe me, Niles, your getting passed up like this has drained every drop of joy from this.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you.  You're a good brother. _Niles exits the caf e.  Roz comes over and hugs Frasier. _

speaker: Frasier
text: YES!!!  I got in, I got in!  I got... shout it from the rooftops!  Lattes for everyone!  This is the proudest day of my life! _Niles has reentered the caf e to get his coat and sees Frasier rejoicing.  He gives him an icy glare._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_puts a hand on Niles's shoulder_] Of course, what really matters is family.  _Niles disgustedly takes Frasier's hand off and exits.  FADE TO:  Scene Five -- Frasier's Apartment In the kitchen, Martin is dangling a piece of meat above Eddie._

speaker: Martin
text: Beg!  Come on, boy, we've been working on this, you can do it. Beg?

speaker: Martin
text: Sit!  Good boy! [_he gives him the meat_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, what are you doing?

speaker: Martin
text: I'm teaching Eddie a new trick.

speaker: Frasier
text: With my twenty-six-dollar-a-pound imported prosciutto?

speaker: Martin
text: Aw, wait'll you see it.  It's worth it!

speaker: Frasier
text: Not unless he can sing the love duet from _Tosca._

speaker: Martin
text: Where you going?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_getting his coat_] Down to the Empire Club.  I've come to a moral decision.  I'm going to insist that they give Niles my membership.

speaker: Martin
text: [_sitting down in his chair_] Wow!  That's a hell of a gesture.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes well, I put myself in Niles' place.  After all, he's spent the last fifteen years diligently trying to climb Seattle's social ladder, then I waltz in and within two years I'm known throughout the city.  To top it all off, I end up grabbing the prize he's wanted most of all.  It just isn't fair.

speaker: Martin
text: You're a good kid, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Dad. [_Daphne enters, carrying a laundry basket_] I might as well say this while I still can: "If anyone needs me... I'll be at my club."

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, yes, the club.  The club that I helped you get into. Of course, now that you're done with me, I'm just cast aside... [_hangs her head_] unappreciated, unloved, and forgotten.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes well, I see the prosciutto isn't the only imported ham in the house.

speaker: Daphne
text: Give me your shirt.  I'm not going down without a full load. [_Martin takes off his shirt_] Have you got anything white?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, but you're not getting 'em.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.  Hello, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Niles. _Niles turns to speak to Daphne, but she has already disappeared out the door, lowering his spirits further._

speaker: Niles
text: Just passed Frasier in the hall.  Where was he off to?

speaker: Martin
text: He went to the Club.

speaker: Niles
text: No wonder he was evasive.  I hope you don't mind my stopping by.  I just had to get out of the house, and Lord knows I had no place else to go. [_he collapses on the couch_]

speaker: Martin
text: You know, Niles, you may get into that club yet.

speaker: Niles
text: What are you talking about?

speaker: Martin
text: That's why Frasier went down there: to tell them to give his spot to you.

speaker: Niles
text: [_sits up_] Dad, is this one of your sick jokes?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I thought you'd be happy!  He's giving up his own membership.

speaker: Niles
text: What exactly did you think I would be happy about?!  This is humiliating -- my big brother going down there to make them take me?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, his heart's in the right place.  You could show a little gratitude.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, they made their decision.  If they didn't take me on my own merits I certainly don't want them to take me out of pity. I don't care if they invite me now, I don't even care if they beg!

speaker: Martin
text: Good boy!  _Niles exits.  FADE TO:_  **HE AIN'T HEAVY...HE'S MY BROTHER** _Scene Six -- The Empire Club Frasier is once again at the Empire Club.  He sees Wentworth._

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me, is the club president here?

speaker: Wentworth
text: Yes, Dr. Crane.  Mr. Drake is over there. _He points to a slightly elderly gentleman sitting in one of the central leather armchairs._

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me, Mr. Drake?

speaker: Drake
text: Yes?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dr. Frasier Crane.

speaker: Drake
text: [_shakes hand with Frasier_] Oh yes, of course!  The new blood.  Please, sit down.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you. [_does so_] Sir, I've come here on a matter of personal business.  It's about my brother, Niles.  You see, Niles is a sort of... [_sinking into chair_] Oh... ohhhh! Oh my God!  This leather's as soft as a baby's bottom!

speaker: Drake
text: Yes, on family night we bring the babies in and do a blindfold comparison test.

speaker: Drake
text: [_stern_] That's a joke, Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_suddenly laughing_] Oh, yes!  Yes, indeed, yes.  Darned good one too, sir.  Yes, as I was saying, although my brother may seem a bit priggish at times, believe me, he's one of the most discriminating people I've ever known.  In fact, I think you'd be hard pressed to find a bigger snob in this room, I mean...

speaker: Wentworth
text: Excuse me, sir, I thought you might enjoy a glass of port.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_Reading label_] 1896?!

speaker: Drake
text: What are you trying to say, Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_raises his glass_] Glad to be aboard, sir! [_then:_] No, no, no... No, I came down here to simply say that my brother deserves membership more than I do, and I would like to step down in his favor.

speaker: Drake
text: Are you serious?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes I am... after all, blood is thicker than port. [_sips the port_] I stand corrected!

speaker: Drake
text: Let me be candid with you, Crane.  We all liked your brother, but some were quite firm about accepting anybody in the entertainment business.  I'm afraid "radio psychiatrist" falls into that category.

speaker: Frasier
text: Radio psychiatrist?  But Niles...

speaker: Frasier
text: Mr. Drake, there's been a terrible mistake.

speaker: Niles
text: No, Frasier, there hasn't.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: Dad told me you would be here, trying to get me into your snooty little club.  Well, you needn't bother.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you don't understand!

speaker: Niles
text: No, you don't understand!  You don't need to be the big brother anymore.  I don't need you to fight my battles!

speaker: Frasier
text: But, Niles-!

speaker: Niles
text: No, butt out!

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay...

speaker: Niles
text: [_to Mr. Drake_] And as for you, you've made it quite clear how you feel about me, so I'd like to share how I feel about you.  I'd sooner spend my leisure time in a smelly bus station than spend one moment with you smug, elitist bigwigs, with your cliched oriental carpets and your overstuffed chairs. [_feels chair_] My God, it's like a baby's bottom! [_then:_] You can't reject me, because I reject you!  Yes, I'm talking to you, Fuzzy!  I prefer to remain Niles Crane, Everyman. [_he throws his arm over Wentworth's shoulders_] Friend of the average Joe.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, they got our names mixed up.  I didn't get in, you did.

speaker: Niles
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: It was you they wanted all along.

speaker: Niles
text: Really?  I'm in? [_to Wentworth_] Good God, don't just stand there, man, fetch me some port and step lively!

speaker: Drake
text: [_to Wentworth_] Will you escort these gentlemen out?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, no, no, no, no... [_sits in chair, and begins to rub his cheek on the wing_] You can't think that I meant those things that I was saying before.

speaker: Wentworth
text: Excuse me, sir, I'm afraid I must ask you to leave.

speaker: Niles
text: [_stands up defiantly_] You and who else? _Someone taps Niles on the shoulder.  Niles turns around and sees a very large butler standing there._

speaker: Niles
text: Ah...

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, come along.  We don't need this club.  Let us leave with the dignity with which we came. [_exits_]

speaker: Niles
text: But-but no... there's, there's been a misunderstanding, I do want to be one of you.  Perhaps you could put me on probation... _The butler tries to drag him away, then just picks him up and carries him out, as Niles continues to plead._

speaker: Niles
text: I could just come part time, or perhaps afternoons, or just one afternoon - Thursday's a slow day - or you can pick the day, I wouldn't even have to talk to anyone, I could just sit in a chair and not say a word... _The last we see of Niles is his hand, as it frantically grabs the doorjamb to delay his bouncing._

speaker: Niles
text: Please, please, please!  Oh, let me stay, I belong here! _As his hand disappears, we FADE OUT.  END OF ACT TWO_
